info.headline: Flash Flood Watch issued January 06 at 3:01PM PST until January 07 at 10:00AM PST by NWS Portland
info.description: .Rain and snowmelt will lead to flooding across portions of southwest Washington and northwest Oregon through Friday. ...FLASH FLOOD WATCH FOR THE EAGLE CREEK FIRE BURN AREA IN EFFECT THROUGH FRIDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Flash flooding and debris flows caused by excessive rainfall and snowmelt are likely over the Eagle Creek Fire Burn Area. * WHERE...The western Columbia River Gorge on the Oregon side of the river. The communities of Dodson and Warrendale are the most at risk of experiencing additional debris flows and landslides tonight into early Friday morning. * WHEN...Through Friday morning. * IMPACTS...An additional bout of heavier rain over the Eagle Creek Fire Burn Area is expected later tonight into early Friday morning. Residents in the vicinity of the Eagle Creek Burn Area, particularly those in Dodson and Warrendale should be prepared to evacuate. Be sure to stay up to date with information from local authorities. Soils are saturated and at a tipping point. Additional rainfall tonight will likely result in additional debris flows. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - A combination of snowmelt and heavy rain later tonight may lead to additional debris flows in the Eagle Creek burn area. Eight confirmed debris flows and landslides occurred earlier this morning in the western Columbia River Gorge with a period of heavier rain and snowmelt. Additional debris flows and landslides are likely later tonight when heavier rain returns. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood The Flood Watch has been replaced with a Flash Flood Watch in the western Columbia River Gorge on the Oregon side of the river for flash flooding and debris flow potential in the Eagle Creek burn area.
info.instruction: You should monitor forecasts and be prepared to take action should Flash Flood Warnings be issued. Be prepared to evacuate on short notice. Local emergency services are monitoring the situation and will issue a public statement as conditions warrant. PLAN NOW so you will know what to do in an emergency. Keep informed by listening to local radio and television for statements and possible warnings. Follow the advice of public safety officials. There have been several confirmed debris flows within the Eagle Creek Burn Area over the past 24 hours. Large destructive debris flows and mudflows are likely with additional rain later tonight into early Friday morning. Debris flows are likely along streams, in canyons and below mouths of canyons in the warned area. Debris flows could overflow normal channels, crossing roads and impacting structures near or below burned drainages and hillsides. If you are in a low lying area around a stream or creek channel, or you hear rumbling sounds, move to higher ground immediately. Do not drive across a flooded area or into shallow debris even though it may look passable.
